awd_titl_txt: S&AS: INT: COLLAB: Goal-driven Marine Autonomy with Application to Fisheries Science and Management
awd_abstract_narration:
Marine robots can be used to accurately map and track marine life, leading to a better interpretation of variability and migration patterns that are important to fisheries managers in marine protected areas (MPAs).  Principles of engineering and oceanography can be used to maximize the impact of a network of marine robots, but because fisheries managers, oceanographers, and roboticists have different perspectives and knowledge bases, it can be difficult to take advantage of cutting-edge research in each field without significant effort to translate among the groups. Researchers will develop a computational interface that translates human-specified missions of fisheries managers into multi-level planning for a fleet of marine robots to monitor fish populations in a dynamic coastal ocean environment. The system will be designed with input from fisheries managers through a series of workshops, and will be field-tested at Gray's Reef National Marine Sanctuary, a federally-managed MPA off the coast of Georgia.  The research will lead to more accurate and effective ways to monitor fish populations in MPAs, as well as breakthroughs in key areas of artificial intelligence and autonomous systems. Many of the results will be applicable to other smart and autonomous systems in challenging environments.  In addition, the project will train graduate students and broaden undergraduate education in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM), and offer a number of outreach activities, including working with the University of Georgia Marine Extension service to develop a summer camp for middle and high school students.

The project is focused on developing an intelligent physical system (IPS) that consists of a heterogeneous fleet of marine robots, cooperatively tracking fish movement and surveying the habitat with minimum request for human intervention. The IPS will translate the human-specified missions of fisheries managers into goal-driven task designs for each robot, and automatically generate executable plans for the networked mobile sensing agents. The system will autonomously and persistently collect in-situ measurements and acoustic detections of fish species while maintaining multi-scale data streams and constructing multiple spatial-temporal maps reflecting the conditions of the ecosystem. The research aims to discover the hotspots (e.g., spatial locations with sustained congregations of fish), as well as illuminate more information about how and when fish move among these hotspots. This goal is quite challenging due to a number of gaps between project needs and the state-of-art autonomy research. Researchers will address the challenges through new developments that accomplish three main tasks: (1) Developing the goal-driven marine autonomy for fish habitat survey, (2) realizing the goal-driven autonomy on physical systems, and (3) evaluating the developed framework through real-life field work, experiments, and data analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This report documents the research carried out under National Science Foundation grant #S&AS-1849131 from February 2019 through the end of January 2022. The scope of the research problem addresses how an intelligent physical system can robustly adapt to unexpected events in complex, dynamic environments such as those found in marine sanctuaries. The solution involves a framework that merges the concepts of goal-driven autonomy and computational metacognition and extends an architectural artifact known as the Metacognitive Integrated Dual-Cycle Architecture (MIDCA). The work defines what it means for an intelligent physical system to be cognizant and taskable in terms of its goals and the operations on those goals. We examine the hypothesis that intelligent physical systems using goal-driven marine autonomy will outperform standard robotic approaches and executed multiple experiments whose results confirm this hypothesis in representative marine environments.

To test the project hypothesis, we investigate three major research objectives. They are as follows.

  1. To develop a computational autonomy framework for fish habitat surveys;
  2. To implement the framework on physical systems; and
  3. To evaluate the concept through laboratory experiments, real-life field work,[1] and data analysis.

Many issues exist concerning differing perspectives with respect to control theory assumptions in marine environments and those of cognitive systems and goal-driven autonomy. However, we have developed a general three-layer framework (see Figure 1 image) that bridges many of the differences and unifies the most important concepts of both. Most of the research from this project concerns the top-most level in blue (i.e., the GDA layer) and most other collaborators in the overall NSF effort (Georgia Tech, Michigan State, and the Skidaway Institute) focus on the lower level in orange (i.e., the CDA layer). Note however that preliminary work was performed that does address the middle level in green.

Over the three-year extent of this project, we conducted many research activities and laboratory experiments that resulted in significant outcomes that bear on theory, design, and implementation. The MIDCA architecture and our goal-driven framework distinguishes themselves with respect to the premise that intelligent decisions and resulting behavior are most effective when goal reasoning is placed central in the set of cognitive processes and metacognition is taken to be a first-class process that mediates cognition. We have made extensive progress formalizing both the goal reasoning process and computational metacognition

This work has furthered a new area of artificial intelligence and autonomous cognitive systems called goal-driven autonomy (more generally goal reasoning). Rather than depend upon humans or external input to provide a goal for a system to achieve through the execution of automated planning, GDA theory provides a framework and an approach for an agent to determine independently when new problems arise, and hence new goals are warranted. The approach also enables goals to change when outdated, dropped when no longer useful, delegated to other agents when they can better achieve them, and to recognize when complex goals are actually achieved in ambiguous situations. These ideas enable systems to transcend the constraints and limitations placed on them by the status quo that views goals as simple predicate states to be achieved by static plans through the effects of executed plan steps.


[1] Performed at Gray?s Reef National Marine Sanctuary, a federally managed area off the coast of Savannah, Georgia.

  • Goal-driven autonomy (GDA) performs goal operations given beliefs about the world. Control-driven autonomy (CDA) manages actuators and updates sensor values. Mediating between these, sets of belief states are mapped to discrete predicates; actions are translated to control parameters.
